title: Rex Sanders
text:
Wing Commander Rex Southern Sanders (14 December 1922 – 10 May 2017) was a <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a> navigator who won a DFC for his service in the Second World War and an AFC for his part in secret photographic and radar reconnaissance missions over the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> in the 1950s in the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a>.
Life.
Sanders, who was born in <a href="London">London</a>, joined the Royal Air Force in April 1941 and was trained as a navigator in <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. He took part in 33 bombing runs, including <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, as part of <a href="No.%2078%20Squadron%20RAF">78 Squadron</a>. After the war, Sanders was selected for training in a 'Special Flight' who undertook training in <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a> on <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force">USAF</a> <a href="North%20American%20B-45%20Tornado">RB-45C</a> aircraft. After the training, the aircraft were flown to an RAF base in <a href="Norfolk">Norfolk</a>, England, and given <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force%20roundels">RAF roundels</a> and the applicable colour schemes. Several missions were then flown with Sanders acting as navigator and photographic operative.
In April 1954, whilst flying a reconnaissance mission over <a href="Kyiv">Kiev</a>, the aircraft was targeted by the Soviet air defence and MiG fighters were scrambled to try and intercept the RB-45C, but the MiGs could not reach the same height as Sanders' bomber ().
In later years, Sanders specialised in guided weapons (most notably the <a href="PGM-17%20Thor">Thor programme</a>) and also acted as an advisor to the <a href="Pakistan%20Air%20Force">Pakistan Air Force</a>. He retired from <a href="Active%20duty">active service</a> in 1977, when he was awarded his OBE.
